awd_titl_txt: A Mechanism of Flash Sintering of Ionic Ceramics
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Traditional densification of ceramics powders into a functional component usually takes at least several hours. In 2010, a group of scientists discovered that nearly instantaneous full densification can occur (within five seconds) for certain ceramics when a high-level voltage or current pass through a compact of these ceramic powders. Thus, this rapid densification technique was named flash sintering. Since then, flash sintering has become one of the most promising techniques for ceramics processing. However, the mechanisms for this rapid sintering process are unclear; this project attempts to reveal the underlying reasons. The experimental work in this study is complemented by computational modeling, enabling a more comprehensive understanding on the rapid densification mechanisms of flash sintering of ceramic powders. This new knowledge then serves as fundamental guidance to extend the flash sintering technique into a wider range of ceramic materials. Graduate and undergraduate students (including minority and other underrepresented students) are being trained in mechanical engineering and materials science and engineering for careers in academia or high-technology manufacturing. Virtual reality technology is used to provide an immersive and interactive teaching and learning environment for materials sciences topics, and helps to educate a workforce capable of using adaptive new technologies in a rapidly changing society.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The technique, flash sintering, has demonstrated the ability to rapidly densify powder compacts of ceramic materials. In this technique, an applied electric field initiates a "flash" event and sintering occurs within a few seconds (at a threshold temperature for a given applied electric field). Although flash sintering has been observed in a variety of ceramic systems, the exact effects of electric field or current on enhancing the densification rate and influencing the microstructure evolution remain elusive, apart from the known thermal runaway Joule heating ohmic mechanisms. A series of experimental and theoretical modeling research activities are being carried out on ionic ceramic systems to clarify the thermal and non-thermal factors of electric field in the flash sintering process. In situ nanoscale imaging is used to observe the flash sintering process of yttrium-stabilized zirconia ceramic systems as a function of applied electric field, providing insights into the flash sintering mechanism. In addition, multiscale atom-to-continuum modeling is being used to simulate the flash sintering process of ionic ceramics in the presence of an electric field. The modeling is revealing the rapid densification mechanisms of flash sintering of ionic ceramics at the atomic level. Students are being educated to become experts in the practice of experimental and computational aspects of ceramic sintering technologies. As a result, graduates are being well prepared to create sustainable engineering solutions to complex problems, and thereby contributing to the cutting-edge of science and technology of ceramics processing and materials science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has yielded significant outcomes that address both the intellectual merit and broader impacts as defined by the NSF merit review criteria. The research focused on unraveling the flash sintering (FS) mechanism in ionic ceramics, a novel and energy-efficient process with potential to revolutionize materials manufacturing.

Intellectual Merit. The project has made substantial contributions to the fundamental understanding of flash sintering. Through a combination of in-situ nanoscale imaging and multiscale modeling, the research team has elucidated key aspects of the FS mechanism, including the role of electric fields in enhancing mass transport and promoting densification (W Xu, A Maksymenko, S Hasan, JJ Meléndez, E Olevsky, Effect of external electric field on diffusivity and flash sintering of 8YSZ: a molecular dynamics study, 2021, Acta Materialia 206, 116596). The development of reactive molecular dynamics simulations has enabled a deeper understanding of the atomic-level processes involved in FS, providing insights into the behavior of ions and vacancies under the influence of electric fields (K Polifrone, C Delaney, MS Hasan, H Bayat, C Foronda, E Olevsky, W Xu, An Atomistic Modeling Study of Electric Field Effect on Sintering Mechanisms of Zirconia, 2024, TMS Annual Meeting & Exhibition, 1819-1826). The integration of experimental observations and computational modeling has led to the establishment of a comprehensive FS mechanism, clarifying the interplay of thermal and non-thermal effects in this process. The project's findings have been disseminated in 15 different publications through peer-reviewed papers, conference papers and presentations, and graduate theses, contributing to the advancement of knowledge in materials science and engineering.

Broader Impacts. Beyond its scientific contributions, the project has had a significant broader impact. It has fostered the development of human resources by providing extensive research training and mentorship to undergraduate and graduate students, totaling about 30 different students, and more than half of them are underrepresented minority students. The project's interdisciplinary nature has encouraged collaboration and knowledge exchange across various fields, including materials science, mechanical engineering, and electrical engineering. The integration of research and education has enriched teaching and learning experiences, exposing students to cutting-edge research and fostering a deeper understanding of scientific inquiry. The project has also contributed to the development of physical and institutional infrastructure by establishing a unique platform for scientific studies and student training in advanced manufacturing of engineering materials. The dissemination of research findings through publicly accessible websites has further broadened the project's impact, promoted transparency and encouraged further exploration in the field. Moreover, the project has actively promoted diversity and inclusion in STEM fields by involving students from underrepresented minority groups, contributing to a more equitable and representative scientific community.

In addition, the project has made a significant impact on education through the integration of virtual and augmented reality (VR/AR) with research computer simulation results. This innovative approach has enhanced the visualization and understanding of complex atomistic structures and processes, making them more accessible to students. The development of educational tools like “Crystal Craft” has the potential to transform the way students learn about materials science and engineering, fostering greater engagement and comprehension. This integration of cutting-edge technology with research outcomes represents a valuable contribution to the educational landscape, with the potential to inspire and motivate future generations of scientists and engineers.

Conclusion. This project has successfully addressed both the intellectual merit and broader impacts criteria of the NSF. The research findings have significantly advanced the understanding of flash sintering mechanisms in ionic ceramics, with potential implications for various industries. The project's emphasis on education and outreach has fostered the development of human resources and promoted diversity and inclusion in STEM fields. The innovative integration of VR/AR technology with research outcomes has further enhanced the project's educational impact. The project's outcomes demonstrate the power of interdisciplinary research and the importance of integrating research and education to drive innovation and address societal challenges.
